newsitem.title: FRANCE: Guerrillas kill 35 in fresh Algeria violence.
newsitem.headline: Guerrillas kill 35 in fresh Algeria violence.

text.p: Moslem rebels killed 34 people in southern Algeria and on Wednesday broke into a training school, shot dead a woman teacher and wounded five other people in a resurgence of violence in the North African country.

Algerian independent newspapers, in detailed accounts of the slaughter of the 34 on Monday night, said 20 were passengers on a bus, forced to get out. They were then slaughtered one by one by having their throats slit.

In the latest killing, Algerian security forces said a "terrorist group" broke into the vocational training school in the small community of Ouled Aich, near the garrison town of Blida, 50 km (30 miles) south of Algiers.
In a statement carried by the official Algerian news agency APS they said the woman teacher was gunned down at 2.10 p.m (1310 GMT) and that among those wounded was a girl pupil.
Monday night's ambush was carried out at a road block with Moslem guerrillas disguised as security forces. The official death toll given earlier for the attack was nine.
The slaughter, among the bloodiest reported in nearly five years of violence, took place south of the Saharan desert town of Laghouat.
It was near a turnoff for Hassi R'mel, Algeria's biggest gas field, where many foreign energy experts work and which is one of the "no-go" zones for which an official pass is needed.
Liberte newspaper said: "A score of terrorists mounted a false road check for more than one hour near Bouterkfine, 50 km (30 miles) south of Laghouat...near the road leading to Hassi R'mel.
"Passengers of a bus were told to get out for identity checks which turned into a nightmare. One by one their throats were coldly slit.
"Some hostages tried to flee. Some were shot by the terrorists and then finished off and mutilated with knives."
Liberte also said the guerrillas stopped an ambulance, killing the driver, a nurse and the husband of a sick woman.
The civilian death toll was the highest reported in the region since an attack last year at Anfous in which 18 people were killed and 15 wounded.
Le Matin newspaper said troops had been sent to the region in a huge manhunt to search towns and villages.
Another independent newspaper, El Khabar, said 20 people on the bus were killed. Others were in a lorry and cars.
Road checks by troops, gendarmerie or police are a common occurrence in the North African country where an estimated 50,000 people have been killed since 1992.
According to Liberte, the guerrillas were acting under the orders of local guerrilla chief Mokhtar Mokhtari, a veteran of the Afhan war and deputy of Habbi Miloud, alias Abou El Walid.
Miloud broke away from the feared Armed Islamic Group (GIA) some months ago after a dispute with GIA leader Djamel Zitouni who was reported to have been killed in July.

The GIA has proved to be one of the most ruthless of the armed Moslem groups who have been trying to topple the authorities since they cancelled a general election in 1992 in which the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) had taken a commanding lead.
